results.title: Marceau on Mime
results.brief_description: Marcel Marceau, world famous French mime, talks about his life and work, about his theories on mime and the history of pantomime in the theatre. He traces mime through the Greek theatre, the commedia del’arte, the Pierrot of the 19th century and the comics of film, like Chaplin, Keaton, Lloyd, and Laurel and Hardy. Marceau started out to be a painter and still does drawings and paintings. He feels that mime is closely related to the graphic arts as well as to music and dance.

results.title: Marc Chagall/the colours of passion
results.creator_credit: Charles Harris and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: Focuses on the diverse artistic achievements of Marc Chagall. Explains his often perplexing subject matter and passion for colour in terms of his stated desire to create a world where anything is possible. Includes examples of his work, along with a discussion of his background and the influences of impressionism, cubism and Russia on his inspiration. Cameraman by Derek Waterman; quotations by Cyril Shaps and commentary by Paul Gregory. Suitable for Years 7-12.

results.title: Marbles
results.brief_description: Edward fears he is losing his grip on reality. Outwardly, he appears grumpier. Eventually he tells his wife she is the only thing that he can remember - but can she help him and what can be done? A poignant film about ageing, shot in black and white featuring Willie Fennell, Moya O’Sullivan and Noni Hazlehurst.

results.title: Marastoon: the place where one is helped
results.creator_credit: Guy L. Cote, J.-P. Olivier Fougeres, Peter Hollander and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Marastoon is situated on the outskirts of Kabul, Afghanistan. It is a government-funded institution created to shelter and train homeless people of all ages. Money saved on food donated by the United Nations World Food Program is used to buy equipment for vocational training and supplies for a handicraft co-operative. A film without words.

results.title: Maps: art and science
results.brief_description: Contrasts early maps with those of today, and then shows the technical procedures required in map making. The results of surveying, aerial photography, and barometric readings are gradually built up until they form a precise representation of the earths surface. Shows the various stages of the process in Sweden.

results.title: Maps: an introduction
results.brief_description: Describes how maps are made by showing a class constructing a map from a model of a town. Depicts the use of a legend and shows how a scale is derived. Illustrates how to locate a community on a world globe and on other maps. No other credits available.

results.title: Maps are fun
results.brief_description: This film deals with the fundamental principles of map reading: scales, colour, symbols, and indexes and their uses are demonstrated. The whole film is designed as a preliminary introduction to the study of maps.

results.title: Maps & globes: An introduction
results.creator_credit: Roger Branson, James Ganzer and FilmFair Communications
results.brief_description: An introduction to the use of maps and globes. Covers scale direction and legend work as well as latitude and longitude.

results.title: Mappings
results.brief_description: Develops a concept of the interchangeability of the words ‘function’ and ‘mapping’. Shows a ‘function machine’ which responds predictably to a given numerical stimulus and gives the rule underlying the response. Good use of comical sketches to explain mathematical equations. From the series “Vision in mathematics”.

results.title: Mapping Australia
results.creator_credit: John Richardson, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows the stages in the production of maps, including aerial photography, ground surveys, and their conversion into map manuscripts. Show relationships of mapping to mineral and industrial development by tracing the stages in aluminium production from the initial discovery of bauxite at Weipa to the production plant at Bell Bay.
